On Mon, Jan 21, 2002 at 01:25:07PM -0500, Scott Stirling wrote:

> The closest thing to that that I've seen is Joshua, a JINI based JUnit framework, but it looks dead.
> 
> http://cs.allegheny.edu/~gkapfham/research/joshua/index.html?target=offsite
> 

Not dead; it just so happens that the supporting faculty member has been 
involved with other work and unable to devote the time to polishing his current
working version of the tool so that it can be released to the public.  Other
research projects have prevented me from becoming more involved with Joshua
development. Anyone interested in collaborating on the development of a new
version of Joshua over the summer?

In light of all this: it appears like Joshua is really not going to be 
beneficial to the point in question.  Joshua is used if you want to distribute
the execution of test suites.  It is not particularly suited if you want to 
actually test a distributed application.  

When I am testing complicated distributed systems, I sometimes move away from 
a test automation framework.  Instead, I configure my distributed services to 
provide logging information (a la log4j or some other tool), and then conduct 
different types of manual tests.  Or, I might use a test automation tool to 
execute a series of test sequences and then investigate the logs manually.  I 
have found that the usage of fault-injection on a distributed system often 
helps me to understand system behavior in off-nominal situations.

If you believe some of the contributors on the Jini-Users mailing list, they
think that they do not need to test their applications if they use Jini (grin).
I would point you to the links, but the online archive appears to be down:

http://archives.java.sun.com/cgi-bin/wa?A0=jini-users&D=1
